MUSC122.description: A continuation of MUSC 121 with the addition of basic instrumentation and arranging.

MUSC123.title: Diction for Singers I (English/Italian)
MUSC123.description: Basic principles of diction for singers in English/Italian presented through the use of the International Phonetic Alphabet.

MUSC124.title: Diction for Singers II (French)
MUSC124.description: Basic principles of diction and the International Phonetic Alphabet for singers in French.

MUSC125.title: Diction for Singers III (German)
MUSC125.description: Basic principles of diction and the International Phonetic Alphabet for singers in German.

MUSC128.title: Improvisation Without Borders
MUSC128.description: This course is an introductory exploration of musical improvisation in non-style specific sound environments. An emphasis will be placed on learning through hands-on performance with one's instrument, voice, and/or computer.

MUSC129.title: Aural-based Musicianship
MUSC129.description: This course is a study in ear-based performance and analysis, and engages with topics from applied music cognition. This course does not rely on conventional Western ''five-line staff'' musical notation.

MUSC130.title: Tonal Musicianship Skills I
MUSC130.description: Basic tonal musicianship skills, including music notation, basic composition, score analysis, keyboard, sight singing, and ear training.

MUSC131.title: Tonal Theory I
MUSC131.description: Enrollment subject to a placement test. An introduction to tonal music theory and analysis for students who intend to pursue a music degree. Course covers basic principles of melody, counterpoint, rhythm, and meter. Honors version available.

MUSC132.title: Tonal Theory II
MUSC132.description: A continuation of MUSC 131, covering more advanced topics of melody, harmony, counterpoint, rhythm, meter, and form. Honors version available.

MUSC133.title: Tonal Musicianship Skills II
MUSC133.description: A continuation of MUSC 130, with emphasis on intermediate-level musicianship skills.

MUSC135.title: Jazz Theory
MUSC135.description: An introduction to the musical materials of jazz, including chord/scale relationships, functional keyboard skills, and harmonic analysis.

MUSC136.title: Keyboard Skills I
MUSC136.description: Beginning group piano instruction for music majors.

MUSC137.title: Patterns in Music
MUSC137.description: This course provides an introduction to music theory--defined as an examination of the underlying patterns deployed by composers, performers, and listeners in creating and comprehending music within a style--for students whose background is primarily aural and/or outside of the notational practices of Western art music or who want to undertake a study of music theory from that perspective.

MUSC141.title: Survey of Western Music History
MUSC141.description: A chronological survey of the history of Western art music from the Middle Ages to the present. May not count toward the requirements of the music major. May count as credit hours toward graduation, subject to the overall limit on music hours.

MUSC142.title: Great Musical Works
MUSC142.description: The study of selected works from the Western art music tradition, with an emphasis on critical understanding.

MUSC143.title: Introduction to Rock Music
MUSC143.description: A survey of rock music history, culture, and musical styles. The course includes extensive listening and an overview of the music's development and evolution.

MUSC144.title: Introduction to Country Music
MUSC144.description: A survey and investigation of country music from 1920 to the present. This course addresses the music, history, culture, and meaning, across a broad and inclusive of styles, with, with emphasis on critical listening.

MUSC145.title: Introduction to Jazz
MUSC145.description: A survey of jazz music from its origins to the present. The course builds skills in critical listening and blends discussion of musical materials and historical and cultural contexts.

MUSC146.title: Introduction to World Musics
MUSC146.description: The study of music in and as culture. Topics may include the performance cultures of Native America, south Asia, Australia, Africa, east Asia, Southeast Asia, Europe, and the Americas.

MUSC147.title: Introduction to the Music of the Américas
MUSC147.description: An introduction to contemporary Latin(o) American popular music, focusing on how musicians have negotiated an increasingly global popular culture industry.

MUSC148.title: Introduction to Black Music
MUSC148.description: An introduction to Black musical cultures with a focus on understanding how music is made within social, geographical, and political contexts. The course includes experiential learning, live concert attendance, and conversations with practicing musicians in various musical traditions.

MUSC149.title: Introduction to Music and Dance
MUSC149.description: Music and dance as human expression, social ritual, and artistic performance across a wide range of repertories, practices, and historical periods.

MUSC150.title: Introduction to Hip-Hop Music and Culture
MUSC150.description: What are the fundamental understandings and conditions that gave rise to the countercultural phenomenon known as hip-hop? This multimodal, aesthetic movement, fueled by the creativity and ingenuity of Black and Brown youth in the 1970s, challenged consumers of music and popular culture to consider (and take seriously) voices from the margins of society. From the South Bronx to the Dirty South, to West Coast and worldwide, as hip-hop music and culture evolves sonically and stylistically, together we will reflect on hip-hop's origins and maturation, its cultural impact and shortcomings, and its future.

MUSC151.title: Introduction to the American Stage Musical
MUSC151.description: A topical survey of musical theater repertoire from its early inception in 18th-century Europe to current 21st-century incarnations. Various stylistic approaches, historical periods, and creative contributions to the genre will be explored. Examination of case studies through diverse perspectives of class, gender and race will situate the repertoire in a broad artistic and social context.

MUSC155.title: The Art and Culture of the DJ
MUSC155.description: An exploration of the important, often misunderstood role of the DJ in modern musical life, with particular attention to the ways in which DJing challenges traditional notions of music, musicianship, and musical instruments. Guest lectures, demonstrations, and tutorials by visiting DJs form a significant component of the course.

MUSC156.title: Beat Making Lab
MUSC156.description: An introductory hands-on study of the composition of electronic instrumental tracks for hip-hop and dance music. Students make beats, learn about the history and culture of the art form, and examine beat making as a case study in entrepreneurship.

MUSC157.title: Rap Lab
MUSC157.description: A hands-on study of the art of emceeing. Students engage in a rigorous lyricism curriculum, developing the skills to write, recite, and improvise lyrics in live and recorded settings. Students also explore the history of hip-hop culture and analyze the aesthetics of emcees from around the world.

MUSC158.title: Rock Lab
MUSC158.description: An introduction to issues of performance practice in rock music and related styles and genres including, but not limited to, soul, funk, new wave, and punk. Through intensive coaching and rehearsal students learn performance, transcription, arranging, and improvisation.

MUSC161.title: Music Production I
MUSC161.description: An in-depth study of vintage and modern music production techniques for jazz, classical, hip-hop, R&B, rock EDM, folk, and other popular forms of music. A focus on digital and analog recording, Pro Tools, and other DAW software basics, microphone techniques, consoles, signal flow, mixing and mastering techniques.

MUSC163.title: Jazz Improvisation I
MUSC163.description: An introductory course in the development of improvisational skills for the jazz idiom. The primary focus is the introduction of nomenclature, the development of basic jazz vocabulary, and the application of this knowledge using basic jazz tune types.

MUSC164.title: Music of South Asia
MUSC164.description: This course provides a comprehensive overview of the music of South Asia, focusing on India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh. The entire spectrum of musical genres will be covered.

MUSC166.title: Introduction to Composition
MUSC166.description: The study of compositional techniques and the development of individual creative styles through imitative and original writing.

MUSC167.title: Instrumentation
MUSC167.description: Practical exercises in scoring and arranging for various combinations from single instrumental choirs to full concert orchestra, with trial group performances.

MUSC168.title: Basic Conducting
MUSC168.description: Basic conducting techniques, score reading, and music performance evaluation for choral and instrumental groups.

MUSC188.title: Introduction to Women and Music
MUSC188.description: The role of women in performance, composition, patronage, and the music business across a wide range of repertories.

MUSC200.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Keyboard
MUSC200.description: Advanced individual lessons in piano, organ, or harpsichord. Sections by instructor. Honors version available.

MUSC202.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Voice
MUSC202.description: Sections by instructor. Honors version available.

MUSC203.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Strings
MUSC203.description: Advanced individual lessons in violin, viola, cello, string bass, harp, or guitar. Sections by instructor. Honors version available.

MUSC204.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Woodwinds
MUSC204.description: Advanced individual lessons in flute, oboe, clarinet, saxophone, or bassoon. Sections by instructor. Honors version available.

MUSC205.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Brass
MUSC205.description: Advanced individual lessons in horn, trumpet, trombone, tuba, or euphonium. Sections by instructor. Honors version available.

MUSC206.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Percussion
MUSC206.description: Sections by instructor. Honors version available.

MUSC207.title: Advanced Applied Instruction
MUSC207.description: Advanced instruction in a specified instrument offered by the department. Sections by instructor.

MUSC211.title: Ensemble I
MUSC211.description: Sections by ensemble: Symphony Orchestra, Wind Ensemble, Symphony Band, Carolina Choir, Chamber Singers, Glee Club (tenor/bass voices), Glee Club (soprano/alto voices), Piano Ensemble I, Piano Ensemble II, Collaborative Piano, Guitar Ensemble, Jazz Band.

MUSC212.title: Ensemble II
MUSC212.description: Sections by ensemble: UNC Opera, Percussion Ensemble, Gamelan, Charanga Carolina, Global Rhythms, Bluegrass Band, Hip Hop.

MUSC213.title: Ensemble III
MUSC213.description: Sections by ensemble: Marching/ Pep Band, Jazz Lab Band, Chamber Orchestra, University Band.

MUSC214.title: Chamber Music
MUSC214.description: Sections by ensemble: University Chamber Players, String Chamber Ensembles, Woodwind Chamber Ensembles, Brass Chamber Ensembles, Piano Chamber Ensembles, Jazz Combos, Baroque Ensemble/Viol Consort, New Music Ensemble. Honors version available.

MUSC223.title: Piano Literature
MUSC223.description: Survey of keyboard literature from the Baroque era to the present.

MUSC224.title: Piano Pedagogy
MUSC224.description: Problems, materials, and methods of teaching piano to students of all ages.

MUSC225.title: Vocal Pedagogy
MUSC225.description: Practical methodology for teaching voice to students of all experience levels. Topics covered include anatomy, historical pedagogy, national vocal teaching styles, and current trends in voice science.

MUSC226.title: Woodwinds, Brass, Percussion, and Strings Techniques
MUSC226.description: Primarily for students pursing teacher licensure. An introduction to basic performance skills on representative woodwind, brass, percussion, and string instruments.

MUSC227.title: Keyboard, Vocal, and Elementary Music Techniques
MUSC227.description: Primarily for students pursuing teacher licensure. An introduction to basic performance skills in voice and piano, and approaches to teaching elementary music.

MUSC228.title: Principles of Teaching Music
MUSC228.description: A continuation of MUSC 226 and 227, allowing students the opportunity to develop further performance skills and pedagogical techniques in music education. Offered in sections: instrumental, vocal, strings.

MUSC230.title: Tonal Musicianship Skills III
MUSC230.description: A continuation of MUSC 133, with emphasis on intermediate- to advanced-level musicianship skills.

MUSC232.title: Theory III
MUSC232.description: A continuation of MUSC 132, covering topics including chromatic harmony and form. Honors version available.

MUSC233.title: Studies in Performance Practices
MUSC233.description: The study of vocal and instrumental performances practices in specific periods and repertories.

MUSC234.title: World Musics in Theory and Practice
MUSC234.description: Through the use of various ethnomusicological methodologies, students explore a range of non-Western musical systems in their cultural contexts. Topics of study may include aesthetic theories, cultural meaning, and conflict.

MUSC236.title: Keyboard Skills II
MUSC236.description: Continues group piano instruction for music majors begun in MUSC 136.

MUSC239.title: Introduction to Music Technology
MUSC239.description: A practical study of selected aspects of computerized music technology, including one or more of music-notation software, MIDI sequencing, digital sound production and storage, and computer composition.

MUSC240.title: Performance in Southeast Asia: Gongs, Punks, and Shadow Plays
MUSC240.description: The study and comparison of contemporary Southeast Asian performance genres (music, theatre, dance, ritual) in historical and cultural contexts.

MUSC245.title: Dance in Indonesia
MUSC245.description: This course is concerned with the performance and interpretation of Indonesian dance. It covers three areas of study: practical learning of traditional Indonesian dance repertoire, theoretical analyses and interpretation, and learning the music accompanying the dance.

MUSC248.title: Gender on the Musical Stage
MUSC248.description: An exploration of gender on the musical stage in the past and present, with an emphasis on female-identified creators and characters, onstage and behind the scenes.

MUSC251.title: Studies in Medieval and Early Modern Music
MUSC251.description: The study of music in its historical and cultural contexts in the medieval and early modern eras. May not count toward the requirements of the music major. May count as credit hours toward graduation, subject to the overall limit on music hours.

MUSC254.title: Studies in Music History I, Antiquity to 1750
MUSC254.description: A survey of music's development from antiquity to 1750, in its stylistic, geographical, political, social, and cultural contexts.

MUSC255.title: Studies in Music History II, 1750 to the Present
MUSC255.description: A continuation of MUSC 254, surveying music of the period since 1750 in its stylistic, geographical, political, social, and cultural contexts.

MUSC256.title: Advanced Beat Making Lab
MUSC256.description: Building upon the foundations of MUSC 156, this course prepares students in professional beat making techniques within various settings of the music industry. The course implements a module-based instruction model, emphasizing student development in creating multiple extended play projects (EPs) with different utilizations (studio, live performance, screen) concluding with the development of a Final Portfolio review, using the computer-based DAW Ableton 11, MIDI controllers, and synthesizers and samplers accessed in the Music Department's Beat Lab.

MUSC258.title: Musical Movements: Migration, Exile, and Diaspora
MUSC258.description: The musical results of migrations of all types, voluntary or forced, by way of case studies drawn from historical and/or contemporary musics of Africa, the Americas, Asia, and Europe.

MUSC261.title: Music Production II
MUSC261.description: As a continuation of MUSC 161, this course will include more advanced techniques in mixing, mastering, and music production. Listening and ear training with practical exercises will be explored. The work of notable engineers and producers will be looked at with an ear towards their production values and critical listening of the material.

MUSC263.title: Jazz Improvisation II
MUSC263.description: Continuation of MUSC 163, examining more advanced improvisational techniques, harmonic materials, and compositional tune types.

MUSC265.title: Jazz Composition and Arranging
MUSC265.description: Composing and arranging for small- and large-group jazz ensembles.

MUSC266.title: Composition
MUSC266.description: May be repeated for credit. Original compositions in various forms.

MUSC267.title: Orchestration
MUSC267.description: Practical orchestral scoring with emphasis on understanding and imitating historical styles from Mozart through Ravel.

MUSC268.title: Making Music Happen
MUSC268.description: This class is broadly about music teaching, but not exclusively about the formal music teaching that occurs in public and private elementary, middle, and high schools across the U.S. We will embrace an expansive definition of teaching that includes engaging with music as teacher, facilitator, performer, ambassador, and presenter. Because the research and literature in music education and community music is well-developed, we will often borrow strategies and pedagogies that can be applied to nearly any situation to learn and practice how a person can lead others to understand or create music more effectively.

MUSC269.title: Music in the Community
MUSC269.description: Connecting academic inquiry in community music with an experiential project in the making, organization, or documentation of music locally.

MUSC270.title: Critical Approaches to Music: Object Lessons
MUSC270.description: Critical approaches to the study of music through a variety of research approaches and sources, both visual and oral, examining meaning, expression, and values through close analysis.

MUSC271.title: Critical Approaches to Music: Critical Moves
MUSC271.description: Critical approaches to understanding music as a human activity, including questions of embodiment, dis/ability, difference, and power through a variety of research approaches and sources, both visual and oral.

MUSC280.title: Jazz Innovators
MUSC280.description: Musical, historical, cultural, and social issues in jazz studied through the examination of innovative and influential jazz artists.

MUSC281.title: Popular Song in American Culture
MUSC281.description: The relationship between popular song and culture in American society is explored by focusing on an important historical repertoire or interpretive theme.

MUSC282.title: Bach and Handel
MUSC282.description: The culmination of baroque music, emphasizing Bach's cantatas, concertos, organ music, and instrumental music, and Handel's oratorios and operas, all in their cultural contexts. May not count toward the requirements of the music major. May count as credit hours toward graduation, subject to the overall limit on music hours.

MUSC283.title: Haydn and Mozart
MUSC283.description: The high point in Viennese music of the late 18th century, emphasizing Haydn's symphonies and quartets, and Mozart's operas and piano concertos. May not count toward the requirements of the music major. May count as credit hours toward graduation, subject to the overall limit on music hours.

MUSC284.title: Beethoven and His Era
MUSC284.description: Beethoven's music will be studied in the context of social structures and concepts about artists during his lifetime. May not count toward the requirements of the music major. May count as credit hours toward graduation, subject to the overall limit on music hours.

MUSC285.title: Musical Modernism
MUSC285.description: A study of the work of diverse composers characteristic of music since ca. 1880 viewed in their broader artistic and other contexts. May not count toward the requirements of the music major. May count as credit hours toward graduation, subject to the overall limit on music hours.

MUSC286.title: Music as Culture
MUSC286.description: May be repeated for credit if on a different topic. Music in the framework of its social, political, economic, and cultural contexts. Honors version available.

MUSC287.title: Opera as Drama
MUSC287.description: An introduction to music as related to drama, especially the development of opera and related genres. Study of selected works from different periods and styles. Honors version available.

MUSC288.title: The Orchestra and Its Music
MUSC288.description: Study of the symphony orchestra, its instruments, and its historical development from the mid-18th century to the present, and the music it plays, including selected works in a variety of styles.

MUSC289.title: Sounds of War and Revolution
MUSC289.description: Music's roles in war and revolution within various political, social, and cultural contexts. Part of the cluster "War, Revolution and Culture-Transatlantic Perspectives, 1750-1850."

MUSC291.title: Music and Politics
MUSC291.description: The relationship between music and politics studied through a global range of historical and geographical contexts. The course covers specific musical and political manifestations as well as theoretical approaches to the issue.

MUSC292.title: Media and Social Change in Africa
MUSC292.description: The historical and ongoing tradition of protest by African artists with particular focus on the aesthetics, politics, and geography of innovative grassroots movements on the African continent that effect social change through music and film.

MUSC294.title: Bluegrass Music, Culture, and History
MUSC294.description: The history, culture, musical sound, and practice of bluegrass music, with an intensive focus on critical listening. Covers significant performers, musical styles, and both fan and performance culture and meaning.

MUSC296.title: Special Studies for Undergraduates
MUSC296.description: Available only to music majors by permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Intensive study on a particular topic under faculty supervision.

MUSC300.title: Advanced Keyboard Lessons and Recital
MUSC300.description: Advanced individual keyboard lessons leading to a public recital.

MUSC302.title: Advanced Voice Lessons and Recital
MUSC302.description: Advanced individual voice lessons leading to a public recital. Honors version available.

MUSC303.title: Advanced String Lessons and Recital
MUSC303.description: Advanced individual string lessons leading to a public recital. Honors version available.

MUSC304.title: Advanced Woodwind Lessons and Recital
MUSC304.description: Advanced individual woodwind lessons leading to a public recital. Honors version available.

MUSC305.title: Advanced Brass Lessons and Recital
MUSC305.description: Advanced individual brass lessons leading to a public recital. Honors version available.

MUSC306.title: Advanced Percussion Lessons and Recital
MUSC306.description: Advanced individual percussion lessons leading to a public recital. Honors version available.

MUSC307.title: Advanced Composition/Recital
MUSC307.description: This course is conceived as a culminating project that showcases a student's original musical compositions.

MUSC308.title: Intermediate Lessons in Conducting
MUSC308.description: Intermediate conducting for instrumental or vocal ensembles.

MUSC309.title: Advanced Lessons in Conducting
MUSC309.description: May be repeated for up to six hours of credit. Advanced conducting for instrumental or choral ensembles.

MUSC330.title: Advanced Study in Music Theory
MUSC330.description: This course will address a particular issue in music theory as it pertains to a genre, repertoire, composer, questions of harmony, rhythm, form or musical structure in Western, non-Western, jazz, or popular musics. Subject matter will vary with instructor. May be repeated for credit if on a different topic. Permission of instructor required.

MUSC331.title: Musical Form and Analysis
MUSC331.description: The study of analytical techniques as applied to significant works of the period.

MUSC332.title: Counterpoint
MUSC332.description: The study of two-, three-, and four-voice counterpoint, for example in the style of Palestrina, Bach, or 20th-century idioms.

MUSC333.title: Analysis of Popular Music
MUSC333.description: Analysis and transcription of blues, rock, ballads, and jazz, with an emphasis on rock music since 1955.

MUSC338.title: Analysis of Music since 1900
MUSC338.description: The study of analytical techniques as applied to significant works of the period.

MUSC351.title: Critical Approaches to Music: Guided Research
MUSC351.description: An intensive research-based course resulting in an original paper and/or creative work on a topic of the student's own development and presentation of the same.

MUSC355.title: History and Culture of Music
MUSC355.description: Course will address a particular genre, composer, compositional issue, or repertoire, including non-Western and popular musics. Subject matter will vary with the instructor. May be repeated for credit if on a different topic. Honors version available.

MUSC361.title: Advanced Vocal Production
MUSC361.description: An in-depth study of recording, editing, mixing, and producing vocals with widespread applications for commercial and media projects. The course will cover vocal production for podcasts, radio, audition tapes, voice overs/ADR, animation/TV/film, and commercial single/EP/album releases. The collective projects throughout the semester will be the start of a professional portfolio for students interested in pursuing a career in audio production. The course will ensure students have knowledge and experience producing their own professional recordings in a workforce where media and self-promotion is prevalent.

MUSC363.title: Studies in Jazz
MUSC363.description: May be repeated for credit if on a different topic. Advanced study on a selected topic in jazz. Topics will vary and may address a particular genre, composer, performance practice, compositional issue, or repertoire.

MUSC364.title: UNC Summer Jazz Workshop
MUSC364.description: Lectures on theory and improvisation, small ensemble coaching, and instrument-specific master classes in a classroom/lecture format. Intensive listening component through required attendance at four evening concerts. Final public student concert for a community audience. Can be repeated for credit.

MUSC366.title: Scoring for Film and Video Games
MUSC366.description: Practical, hands-on training in the art of composing music for film and video games. In addition to analyzing and discussing influential film/game music, the course develops skills such as orchestration, underscoring, musical narrative, and thematic development. Students enrolled in the course are expected to have some prior experience composing and notating music for a variety of instruments and ensembles.

MUSC381.title: Inside the Song: Analysis of Songcraft
MUSC381.description: Explore form, structure, and narrative in American popular song during the era of recorded sound. Students will analyze the elements of different songs -- melody, lyrics, harmony, musical arrangement, form, narrative, and structure. Students will write songs using different models and forms; edit and revise their songs; and perform those songs publicly. Familiarity with basic chords and melodies expected.

MUSC390.title: Seminar in Music
MUSC390.description: Detailed investigation of a specific musical topic from historical and/or theoretical perspectives. Honors version available.

MUSC471.title: Instrumental Performance Repertory
MUSC471.description: Advanced study of selected performance issues.

MUSC493.title: Music Internship
MUSC493.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Internship directly related to the study, practice, or the business of music. Students must complete at least 100 hours and submit a journal and report upon completion of the internship. No more than three credit hours may count toward the requirements of the music major. Excess hours may count as credit hours toward graduation, subject to the overall limit on music hours.

MUSC676.title: Digital Media and Live Performance
MUSC676.description: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. Intended for students from various majors, this course provides a foundation in the history, theory, and practice of developing live, technologically-intensive, multimedia performance works. The course analyzes new media masterworks, addresses techniques of interdisciplinary collaboration, and offers workshops in specific software/technology applications.

MUSC691H.title: Senior Honors Thesis in Music I
MUSC691H.description: Admission by permission of the honors advisor. Independent study by a student who has been designated a candidate for undergraduate honors in music.

MUSC692H.title: Senior Honors Thesis in Music II
MUSC692H.description: Continuance and completion of an honors thesis in music.

MUSC750.title: Resources and Methods of Musicology I
MUSC750.description: Introduction to the field of musicology, including its scope, methodology, and bibliography. Taught in three-week modules, each directed by a different member of the academic faculty. Individual modules will include music history, music theory, ethnomusicology, music aesthetics, and cultural studies.

MUSC751.title: Resources and Methods of Musicology II

MUSC890.title: Special Studies
MUSC890.description: The faculty assists and advises graduate students in work on particular research projects. Available to musicology graduate students only (M.A.T. students taking special studies must register under MUSC 471).

MUSC991.title: Dissertation Colloquium. 1
MUSC991.description: Forum for group discussion of on-going dissertation work and professional development.

MUSC992.title: Master's (Non-Thesis)
MUSC992.description: MUSC 992 is required for all graduate students enrolled in the MA/PhD program in Musicology. Graduate students should take this course in fall semester of their second year of completing the program's MA requirements. Required assignments will teach skills that are key for successful completion of the PhD.

PHIL51.title: First-Year Seminar: Who Was Socrates?
PHIL51.description: Socrates is the quintessential philosopher--a man for all seasons, a foundational figure of the West.

PHIL52.title: First-Year Seminar: Reason and Religion at the Dawn of Modern Science
PHIL52.description: Students will read some of the most important philosophical reflections of the 17th and 18th centuries.

PHIL53.title: First-Year Seminar: Theories in Human Nature
PHIL53.description: Students will explore a variety of issues that arise when human beings begin to reflect on our own natures and will be introduced to main theories that have been developed. Honors version available.

PHIL54.title: First-Year Seminar: Thinking about Time
PHIL54.description: What is time? Do the past and the future exist, or only the present? Is the "flow of time" an objective feature of reality?

PHIL55.title: First-Year Seminar: Paradoxes
PHIL55.description: Paradoxes have been a driving force in philosophy since the fourth century BCE. They force us to rethink old ideas and conceptions.

PHIL56.title: First-Year Seminar: Abortion
PHIL56.description: A general philosophical discussion of the value of life, the evil in death, and the wrongness of killing.

PHIL57.title: First-Year Seminar: Race and Affirmative Action
PHIL57.description: The goal of the course is to get a mature and correct understanding of race, racism, and affirmative action.

PHIL58.title: First-Year Seminar: From Vengeance to Mercy: Dealing with Evil
PHIL58.description: This course will explore the ethical dimensions of the responses to evil that we have developed over history. Revenge, retribution, reparation; hatred, resentment, forgiveness; punishment, pardon, mercy.

PHIL59.title: First-Year Seminar: Proofs of the Existence of God
PHIL59.description: We will examine efforts in the history of philosophy to prove that God exists or that God does not exist. Our aim is to articulate and understand some of the underlying philosophical issues that are raised by these proofs and arguments. Honors version available.

PHIL60.title: First-Year Seminar: Plato's Symposium and Its Influence on Western Art and Literature
PHIL60.description: This seminar examines Plato's philosophical and literary masterpiece, The Symposium, and its influence on later artists and writers: we explore the Symposium itself, the ways in which the Symposium influenced later European artists and writers, and the importance of the Platonic view of love and beauty for modern artists and writers. Honors version available.

PHIL61.title: First Year Seminar: The Self: Aspiration and Transformation
PHIL61.description: Novels, memoirs, and aisles of self-help books attest to our desire to transform ourselves. Yet, the idea of self-transformation is puzzling. In this class, we will critically examine the idea of aspiration and transformation.

PHIL62.title: First-Year Seminar: Philosophy with Children
PHIL62.description: This seminar is designed to give students a unique, experiential perspective on philosophical inquiry by combining the philosophical study of ethics with virtual service in the community. We will examine philosophical questions about childhood and engage in philosophical interactions with children about a range of philosophical topics, with an emphasis on ethics and human values. Students perform 30 hours of service at a local K-5 school.

PHIL63.title: First-Year Seminar: Mind, Brain, and Consciousness
PHIL63.description: What are minds and how are they related to bodies?

PHIL65.title: First-Year Seminar: Philosophy through Mathematics
PHIL65.description: This seminar introduces several of the central problems in philosophy through reflection on the nature of mathematics.

PHIL66.title: First-Year Seminar: Ethics: Theoretical and Practical
PHIL66.description: This seminar examines theoretical issues, relativism, utilitarianism, deontological ethics, and virtue ethics.

PHIL67.title: First-Year Seminar: Issues in a World Society: Sports and Competition
PHIL67.description: This seminar examines ethical issues in sports, including Title IX, gender equity, racism, sexism, cheating, violence, and drug use.

PHIL68.title: First-Year Seminar: Moral Life
PHIL68.description: This course will explore the meaning of basic moral concepts as they are understood in philosophy, science, and art. Honors version available.

PHIL70.title: First-Year Seminar: Gateway to Philosophy, Politics, and Economics
PHIL70.description: This course uses insights and techniques from philosophy, politics, and economics to answer questions like: What makes a modern civilization possible? How can our societies continue to improve? What role do property rights, markets, and political action play in creating flourishing civilizations? How do we address environmental degradation, distributive justice, and economic exploitation? Our answers will draw from rational choice theory, utility theory, game theory, public choice economics, etc. Course is limited to PPE minors.

PHIL75.title: First-Year Seminar: Evil
PHIL75.description: What is evil? Who, if anyone, is responsible for it? How different are evil people from the rest of us? How should we respond to them? The course will explore the nature of evil through philosophy, nonfiction, fiction, and film.

PHIL76.title: First-Year Seminar: Is Free Will an Illusion?
PHIL76.description: This course will examine whether our belief in freedom of action is compatible with the modern picture of ourselves. Honors version available.

PHIL77.title: First-Year Seminar: Moral Weakness and Conscience
PHIL77.description: Is man's reason a powerful thing: if one had knowledge or belief about something that should be done, would that be enough to position one to do it?

PHIL78.title: First-Year Seminar: Death as a Problem for Philosophy: Metaphysical and Ethical
PHIL78.description: This course explores both old and new questions regarding death. It will examine the presuppositions and cogency of the classical religious-philosophical conception of death.

PHIL79.title: First-Year Seminar: Words That Bind: The Structure of Constitutions
PHIL79.description: In this seminar we will examine a number of constitutions and try to determine what makes a constitution better or worse, and when it makes sense to borrow constitutional principles from other countries. We will also try our hand at designing a constitution.

PHIL80.title: First-Year Seminar: Short Stories and Contemporary Social Problems
PHIL80.description: We will read short stories and social science articles that address social problems such as child-rearing; social mobility; mass incarceration and race; the opiate crisis; tradition versus science. Students will explore the different ways in which literature, the humanities and the social sciences construct issues of social relevance, the opportunities and limits of these constructions, and what might be gained by using each to understand and respond to these issues.

PHIL85.title: First-Year Seminar: Reason, Religion, and Reality in the Copernican Revolution
PHIL85.description: The arguments by which Galileo and his contemporaries defended the Copernican model of the solar system puzzle philosophers even today. Honors version available.

PHIL86.title: First-Year Seminar: Persons and Identity
PHIL86.description: An introduction to the topic of personal identity, focused on epistemological, ethical, and metaphysical themes. The course examines what personal identity over time consists in, whether and how we can know such identity, under what conditions our personal identity is liable to change, and what this implies for our values and projects.

PHIL89.title: First Year Seminar: Special Topics
PHIL89.description: Special Topics Course. Content will vary each semester.

PHIL101.title: Introduction to Philosophy: Central Problems, Great Minds, Big Ideas
PHIL101.description: An introduction to philosophy focusing on a few central problems, for example: free will, the basis of morality, the nature and limits of knowledge, and the existence of God. Honors version available.

PHIL102.title: Introduction to Philosophy: Central Problems, Great Minds, Big Ideas
PHIL102.description: This course introduces students to the experience of thinking like philosophers and aims at developing students' capacity to think carefully and critically about philosophical arguments. The central skills to be practiced are those involved in productive philosophical discussion. The course emphasizes how philosophy is and has been done through dialogue, that philosophical claims must be tested against the objections of one's fellow thinkers, and how philosophical disagreement can lead to productive insights.

PHIL105.title: How to Reason and Argue: An Introduction to Critical Thinking
PHIL105.description: A course on how to identify, analyze, and evaluate arguments by other people and how to construct arguments. Topics include argument reconstruction, informal logic, fallacies, introductory formal logic, probabilistic reasoning.

PHIL110.title: Philosophical Texts that Changed the World: An Introduction to Philosophy through Great Works
PHIL110.description: An introduction to philosophy focusing on several great books from the history of Western philosophy. See course description at the department's website for which books will be covered each semester. Students may not receive credit for both PHIL 110 and PHIL 113. Honors version available.

PHIL111.title: Philosopher Queens: World Philosophies through Women's Texts
PHIL111.description: This course provides an introduction to world philosophies through close readings of philosophical texts attributed to or written by women in different time-periods from across the globe. We will practice the art of reading, understanding, and philosophically engaging with great historical works of philosophy while also examining the political inequalities, social structures, and contemporary practices from within which these women philosophers wrote and were trying to make their voices heard.

PHIL112.title: Making Sense of Ourselves
PHIL112.description: An examination of some of the most influential attempts to understand human beings, their lives, and their moral and political values. Authors may include Plato, Aristotle, and Nietzsche. Honors version available.

PHIL113.title: Philosophical Texts that Changed the World: An Introduction To Philosophy Through Great Works
PHIL113.description: An introduction to philosophy focusing on several great books from the history of Western philosophy. See course description at the department's website for which books will be covered each semester. Special emphasis on practicing, engaging in, and discussing the activity of oral communication and communal deliberation. Students may not receive credit for both PHIL 113 and PHIL 110.

PHIL134.title: Reason, Faith, and God: Philosophy of Western Religion
PHIL134.description: A philosophical inquiry into the problems of religious experience and belief, as expressed in philosophic, religious, and literary documents from traditional and contemporary sources. Honors version available.

PHIL140.title: Knowledge and Society
PHIL140.description: An examination of questions about knowledge, evidence, and rational belief as they arise in areas of social life such as democratic politics, the law, science, religion, and education. Honors version available.

PHIL143.title: AI and the Future of Humanity: Philosophical Issues about Technology and Human Survival
PHIL143.description: This course investigates philosophical issues arising from advanced forms of technology, in particular artificial intelligence, virtual reality, and biological augmentation. We will consider questions about the dangers and benefits of AI, survival in non-biological ways, moral constraints on AI, the relationship between human and machine morality, and others. Honors version available.

PHIL145.title: Language, Communication, and Human and Animal Minds
PHIL145.description: An examination of the differences between natural human languages and other communication systems. Includes a philosophical inquiry into how languages relate to the world and the mind. Honors version available.

PHIL150.title: Theory, Evidence, and Understanding in Science
PHIL150.description: What is distinctive about the kind of knowledge called "science"? What is scientific explanation? How are scientific theories related to empirical evidence? Students may not receive credit for both PHIL 150 and PHIL 151. Honors version available.

PHIL151.title: Theory, Evidence, and Understanding in Science (CommBeyond)
PHIL151.description: What is distinctive about the kind of knowledge called ''science''? What is scientific explanation? How are scientific theories related to empirical evidence? An examination of these and related issues with special focus on developing oral communication skills. Students may not receive credit for both PHIL 151 and PHIL 150.

PHIL154.title: Philosophy of the Social Sciences
PHIL154.description: How do social sciences explain human actions? Are there social facts over and above facts about various individuals? Do values enter into social science?

PHIL155.title: Truth and Proof: Introduction to Mathematical Logic
PHIL155.description: Introduces the theory of deductive reasoning, using a symbolic language to represent and evaluate patterns of reasoning. Covers sentential logic and first-order predicate logic. Honors version available.

PHIL157.title: Logic and Decision Theory
PHIL157.description: A broader discussion of practical reasoning, including inductive and deductive logic, which provides a good introduction to decision and game theory that is important for the social sciences, especially economics. Honors version available.

PHIL160.title: Virtue, Value, and Happiness: An Introduction to Moral Theory
PHIL160.description: Exploration of different philosophical perspectives about right and wrong, personal character, justice, moral reasoning, and moral conflicts. Readings drawn from classic or contemporary sources. Critical discussion emphasized. Students may not receive credit for both PHIL 160 and PHIL 161. Honors version available.

PHIL161.title: Virtue, Value, and Happiness: An Introduction to Moral Theory
PHIL161.description: Exploration of different philosophical perspectives about right and wrong, personal character, justice, moral reasoning, and moral conflicts. Readings drawn from classic or contemporary sources. Special emphasis on practicing, engaging in, and discussing the activity of oral communication and communal deliberation. Students may not receive credit for both PHIL 160 and PHIL 161.

PHIL163.title: Practical Ethics: Moral Reasoning and How We Live
PHIL163.description: Topics may include war, medical ethics, media ethics, sexual ethics, business ethics, racism, sexism, capital punishment, and the environment. Honors version available.

PHIL164.title: Morality and Business
PHIL164.description: An examination of business ethics and the types of ethical dilemmas people may face in business practices.

PHIL165.title: Bioethics
PHIL165.description: An examination of ethical issues in the life sciences and technologies, medicine, public health, and/or human interaction with nonhuman animals or the living environment. Honors version available.

PHIL170.title: Liberty, Rights, and Responsibilities: Introduction to Social Ethics and Political Thought
PHIL170.description: An examination of major issues in political philosophy, e.g., liberty, individual rights, social responsibility, legal authority, civil authority, civil disobedience. Readings include classical and contemporary writings. Honors version available.

PHIL175.title: Philosophical Foundations of American Democracy
PHIL175.description: This course explores the political philosophies that shaped the United States, such as the Enlightenment, classical republicanism (liberty, self-government, rule of law), and constitutionalism. By reading and discussing a variety of philosophical and historical texts, students will learn how these ideas formed the foundation of American democracy and how later generations continued the effort to form "a more perfect union".

PHIL180.title: Philosophy of Humor
PHIL180.description: A course on philosophical issues related to laughter and humor. Historical and contemporary philosophical theories of humor; connections between traditional issues in aesthetics and humor; moral questions about humor, such as what is involved in a joke being racist/sexist/homophobic; and connections between jokes and various epistemological fallacies.

PHIL185.title: Aesthetics and the Philosophy of Art
PHIL185.description: The nature of art and artworks and their aesthetic appraisal. Honors version available.

PHIL210.title: Wonder, Myth, and Reason: Introduction to Ancient Greek Science and Philosophy
PHIL210.description: The emergence of philosophy in Greece during the sixth century BCE and its development during the classical period. The major figures studied are the Pre-Socratic philosophers, Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle. Honors version available.

PHIL211.title: Perspectives on Gender, Race, and Marginality in Ancient Greek Philosophy, Science, and Medicine
PHIL211.description: This course studies through the examination of several infamous, ignored, or otherwise uncharted Ancient Greek texts the views about gender and race as presented in ancient Greek philosophy, medicine, and science. Our aims are to generate a new understanding of how the male elite used such views to further promote or justify (or perhaps challenge) the existing marginalization and silencing of women, foreigners, and less privileged men.

PHIL213.title: Asian Philosophy
PHIL213.description: An examination of some of the philosophical traditions of Asia. Possible topics include Advaita Vedanta, Nyaya-Vaisheshika, Madhyamaka Buddhism, neo-Confucianism, Mohism, and philosophical Taoism.

PHIL215.title: Medieval Philosophy
PHIL215.description: A survey of medieval philosophy from Augustine through Ockham. Topics: God and the world, faith and reason, knowledge and reality, the problem of universals. Additional main authors: Anselm, Aquinas, Duns Scotus.

PHIL220.title: 17th and 18th Century Western Philosophy
PHIL220.description: A study of some major philosophical works from this period, including works by authors such as Descartes, Spinoza, Locke, Berkeley, Leibniz, Hume, and/or Kant. Honors version available.

PHIL224.title: Existential Philosophy and the Meaning(lessness) of Life
PHIL224.description: A survey of European philosophers in the phenomenological and existentialist traditions. Philosophers studied may include Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Husserl, Heidegger, Sartre, Camus. Honors version available.

PHIL228.title: American Philosophy
PHIL228.description: An exploration of the distinctively American approaches to philosophy from Jonathan Edwards to the present.

PHIL229.title: 20th-Century Western Philosophy
PHIL229.description: An introductory survey of British and Continental philosophy in the 20th century.

PHIL230.title: Mind, Matter, and Metaphysics: the Philosophy of Experience and Reality
PHIL230.description: Topics in metaphysics and/or epistemology, such as: Is your mind different from your brain? Is it possible for us to know anything about the external world? Do we have free will? What distinguishes reasonable from unreasonable belief? Honors version available.

PHIL251.title: Inductive Logic and the Scientific Method
PHIL251.description: This course examines the role that inductive logic plays in scientific reasoning. Questions to be considered include: Are scientific theories distinguished from pseudoscience by being testable against our observations? Can we prove our best scientific theories to be true? Are we justified in making predictions about the future on the basis of past observations? The course examines these and other questions about confirming scientific theories by using the apparatus provided by the probability calculus.

PHIL261.title: Ethics in Action
PHIL261.description: Ethics Bowl provides a unique experiential opportunity for students to apply theory to practical global issues. Students will prepare cases to present locally and at Ethics Bowl competition. Permission of the instructor.

PHIL265.title: Ethics, Politics, and Technology
PHIL265.description: In the near future, our taxis will be driver-less, our wars will be fought by autonomous drones, and our towns will be kept safe by algorithms foreseeing crimes. This course explores the ethical implications of this new technological revolution and invites students to debate the challenges it engenders. We will debate how new technologies ought to be governed and what limits should be imposed on their implementation.

PHIL266.title: Not All Fun and Games: Ethics of Sports
PHIL266.description: An analysis of the moral significance of sports, the nature of sport and competition, and issues such as racism, gender equity, violence, and performance-enhancing drugs.

PHIL272.title: The Ethics of Peace, War, and Defense
PHIL272.description: An analysis of ethical issues that arise in peace, war, and defense, e.g., the legitimacy of states, just war theory, terrorism, weapons of mass destruction.

PHIL273.title: Justice, Rights, and the Common Good: Philosophical Perspectives on Social and Economic Issues
PHIL273.description: This course will focus on justice and the common good, applying theoretical justifications to contemporary social and economic issues. Readings will include classical and contemporary literature on the nature of justice and rights. Honors version available.

PHIL274.title: Race, Racism, and Social Justice: African-American Political Philosophy
PHIL274.description: Race, identity, discrimination, multiculturalism, affirmative action, and slave reparations in the writings of Walker, Delany, Douglass, Cooper, DuBois, King, and Malcolm X. Honors version available.

PHIL275.title: Moral and Philosophical Issues of Gender in Society
PHIL275.description: A survey of feminist perspectives on topics such as the meaning of oppression, sexism and racism, sex roles and stereotypes, ideals of female beauty, women in the workplace, pornography, rape. Honors version available.

PHIL276.title: Ideology, Capitalism, and Critique
PHIL276.description: This course studies how (oftentimes implicit) ideological commitments shape our culture and our social reality. We will explore the Marxist tradition and the Frankfurt School Critical Theory, as well as contemporary applications and critiques of ideology in thinkers such as Jaeggi, Fraser, Shelby, and Haslanger.

PHIL280.title: Morality, Law, and Justice: Issues in Legal Philosophy
PHIL280.description: Explores issues in legal philosophy such as, What is law? Does it serve justice or undermine it? Can punishment be justified? When is a person responsible? Honors version available.

PHIL282.title: Human Rights: Philosophical Interrogations
PHIL282.description: The philosophy of human rights addresses questions about the existence, content, nature, universality, justification, and legal status of human rights. The strong claims made on behalf of human rights frequently provoke skeptical doubts and countering philosophical defenses. These will be addressed through classical and contemporary history of philosophy.

PHIL285.title: Moral and Philosophical Issues in Education
PHIL285.description: A critical examination of the moral and philosophical issues in education: What does it mean to be well educated? What is a liberal education? Honors version available.

PHIL292.title: Field Work in Philosophy: Introducing Philosophy in Primary and Secondary Schools
PHIL292.description: Permission of the instructor. This course combines on-campus structured learning with substantial on-site field work incorporating philosophy into the primary and/or secondary school curriculum. Philosophy subjects and school partners will vary by semester.

PHIL294.title: Philosophy across the Lifespan
PHIL294.description: This is a high-impact service-learning course that aims to promote experiential learning in philosophy by combining traditional elements of classroom study with service in the community (HI-SERVICE). Students will have the unique opportunity to teach and learn philosophy alongside older adults in the Triangle area, thereby integrating the academic study of philosophy with community engagement.

PHIL330.title: Metaphysics
PHIL330.description: An examination of general theories of the nature of reality. What kinds of things exist? What are space, time, and causation? Are abstract entities (such as numbers) real?

PHIL335.title: Theory of Knowledge
PHIL335.description: What is knowledge and how does it relate to belief, justification, and truth? What makes beliefs reasonable or irrational? Can skepticism be defeated?

PHIL340.title: Philosophy of Mind
PHIL340.description: The mind-body problem, the nature of thinking, the puzzles of consciousness, and the qualitative character of felt experience.

PHIL345.title: Philosophy of Language
PHIL345.description: Survey of major topics in contemporary philosophy of language. Topics may include truth and meaning, speech acts, reference, descriptions, names, and demonstratives.

PHIL351.title: Philosophy of Physics
PHIL351.description: Topics may include the nature of space and time, the ontological status of fields and energy, or causation and locality in quantum physics. Honors version available.

PHIL352.title: Sex and Death, Life and Health, Species and Evolution: The Philosophy of Biology
PHIL352.description: Philosophical issues raised by biological theories, which may include the logical structure of evolutionary theory, fitness, taxonomy, the notion of a living thing, reductionism, evolutionary explanations, or teleology.

PHIL353.title: Minds and Machines: Philosophy of Cognitive Science
PHIL353.description: Philosophical questions raised by linguistics, computer science, cognitive psychology, and neuroscience. Topics may include the innateness of language, artificial intelligence, and the neural correlates of consciousness. Honors version available.

PHIL354.title: Quantum Mechanics, Weirdness, and Reality
PHIL354.description: An interdisciplinary course on the weirdness of quantum mechanics and the problem of interpreting it. Nonlocality, the measurement problem, superpositions, Bohm's theory, collapse theories, and the many-worlds interpretation.

PHIL355.title: Intermediate Mathematical Logic
PHIL355.description: Quantificational logic with identity; basic meta-theory; modal logic.

PHIL357.title: Induction, Probability, and Confirmation
PHIL357.description: Current accounts of evidence and observation, the confirmation of scientific theories, the logic of inductive reasoning, and the metaphysics and epistemology of chance.

PHIL360.title: Major Developments in Ethics: Historical and Philosophical Perspectives
PHIL360.description: PHIL 160 recommended. Major developments in the history of moral philosophy, from Plato to Nietzsche. Honors version available.

PHIL362.title: Contemporary Ethical Theory
PHIL362.description: Using 20th- and 21st-century texts, this course explores some general questions about morality in depth. For example, Is there moral truth? Are any moral rules absolute? Why be moral? Honors version available.

PHIL364.title: Ethics and Economics
PHIL364.description: Recommended preparation, at least one course in ethics (PHIL 160, 163, or 170) or one course in economics. Issues at the intersection of ethics and economics, including value; the relation between values and preferences; rationality; the relevance to economics of rights, justice, and the value of human life.

PHIL368.title: Living Things, Wilderness, and Ecosystems: An Introduction to Environmental Ethics
PHIL368.description: The meaning of environmental values and their relation to other values; the ethical status of animals, species, wilderness, and ecosystems; the built environment; environmental justice; ecofeminism; obligations to future generations. Honors version available.

PHIL370.title: Authority, Freedom, and Rights: Advanced Political Philosophy
PHIL370.description: Advanced discussion of competing philosophical approaches to questions of justice, authority, freedom, rights, and the like, including libertarianism, liberalism, communitarianism, Marxism, and feminism.

PHIL381.title: Philosophy and Film
PHIL381.description: An examination of how philosophical issues are explored in the medium of film. Honors version available.

PHIL384.title: Gateway to Philosophy, Politics, and Economics
PHIL384.description: One course in economics strongly recommended. This interdisciplinary gateway course provides an introduction to subjects and quantitative techniques used to analyze problems in philosophy, political science, and economics. Honors version available.

PHIL390.title: Seminar in Selected Topics
PHIL390.description: Intensive exploration and discussion of selected topics in philosophy. Honors version available.

PHIL392.title: Ethics Research Seminar for Undergraduates
PHIL392.description: This is a capstone course in ethics designed for Parr Center Ethics Scholars completing the Mentored Research capstone project. The seminar will provide a collaborative learning space that will facilitate each student's independent research and writing. This course will begin with survey of major themes in practical ethics before transitioning to a thematically focused study of topics based on the research interests of the students in the course.

PHIL395.title: Undergraduate Research Seminar in Selected Topics
PHIL395.description: This is a philosophical research course for anyone with some background in philosophy and an interest in the topic. Special emphasis is placed on giving students the opportunity to immerse themselves in a research project that leads to an original final research paper.

PHIL396.title: Directed Readings
PHIL396.description: Permission of the instructor. See the director of undergraduate studies of the department.

PHIL397.title: Philosophy Research Seminar for Undergraduates
PHIL397.description: This course is designed to approximate the experience of a graduate seminar in philosophy. The course topic is different each year; class meetings are discussion-based and focused on developing professional writing and research skills. Recommended for all majors and minors.

PHIL411.title: Aristotle
PHIL411.description: An examination of some representative works of Aristotle, with reference to common emphases and basic problems, together with an analysis of their philosophic content. The aim to provide students with a more thorough understanding of the key texts, doctrines, notions, and ideas in Aristotle's philosophy as a whole and with the capacities and confidence to conduct a short, independent, ancient philosophical research project on Aristotle's philosophy.

PHIL412.title: Plato
PHIL412.description: An examination of some representative works in the context of contemporary scholarship.

PHIL415.title: Medieval Philosophy
PHIL415.description: An intensive study of some medieval philosophical author (e.g., Aquinas, Scotus, or Ockham) or topic (e.g., arguments for the existence of God, universals, knowledge of individuals).

PHIL421.title: Rationalism
PHIL421.description: An in-depth study of such rationalist philosophers as Descartes, Spinoza, and Leibniz.

PHIL422.title: Empiricism
PHIL422.description: An in-depth study of such empiricist philosophers as Locke, Berkeley, and Hume.

PHIL423.title: Kant's Theoretical Philosophy
PHIL423.description: An intensive introduction to Kant's accounts of space, time, concepts, perception, substance, causation, and the thinking self through a careful study of his masterwork, The Critique of Pure Reason.

PHIL424.title: Kant's Practical Philosophy
PHIL424.description: This course studies closely Kant's practical philosophy, dedicated to understanding and assessing the answers that Kant gives to classic questions of practical philosophy, such as: What does morality demand from us? What is the morally right course of action? Is morality objective? Do moral norms depend on God?

PHIL426.title: Nietzsche
PHIL426.description: This course examines the philosophy of Friedrich Nietzsche, covering all three conventionally recognized periods of his philosophy in chronological sequence, tracing the historical and philosophical development of his views from the early Birth of Tragedy to the late Twilight of Idols. The main question we will face when studying all these different writings is how Nietzsche tries to solve the problem of nihilism. Completion of one previous PHIL course preferred.

PHIL427.title: Hegel
PHIL427.description: In-depth study of Hegel's systematic philosophy emphasizing its roots in Kant's critical philosophy. Primary focus on Phenomenology of Spirit, supplemented by selections from the Encyclopedia and Philosophy of Right.

PHIL428.title: History of American Philosophy
PHIL428.description: An in-depth study of American contributions to philosophy, including for example the transcendentalists, the pragmatists, Quine, Rorty, and others.

PHIL432.title: The Beginnings of Analytic Philosophy
PHIL432.description: Frege, Russell, Moore, and Wittgenstein among others are considered.

PHIL433.title: Current Issues in Analytic Philosophy
PHIL433.description: Two courses in philosophy other than PHIL 155 strongly recommended. Recent work in epistemology and metaphysics.

PHIL440.title: Philosophy of Mind
PHIL440.description: At least two courses in philosophy other than PHIL 155, including PHIL 340, strongly recommended. An examination of dualism, behaviorism, the identity theory, and forms of functionalism with special focus on the problems of mental aboutness and the problems of consciousness.

PHIL442.title: Philosophical Foundations of Artificial Intelligence
PHIL442.description: This course focuses on advanced philosophical issues tied to artificial intelligence. We will discuss a number of topics concerning how to understand contemporary AI systems, their limits and advantages, as well as the risks and benefits of their application and deployment in real life situations.

PHIL445.title: Advanced Philosophy of Language
PHIL445.description: At least two courses in philosophy other than PHIL 155, including PHIL 345, strongly recommended. A study of important contemporary contributions in philosophy of language. Topics include meaning, reference, and truth.

PHIL450.title: Philosophy of Natural Sciences
PHIL450.description: An in-depth survey of general issues in contemporary philosophy of natural science intended for advanced philosophy students. Topics include confirmation, explanation, theory-choice, realism, reduction.

PHIL451.title: Philosophy of Physics
PHIL451.description: Topics may include the nature of space and time, the ontological status of fields and energy, or causation and locality in quantum physics.

PHIL452.title: Philosophy of Biology
PHIL452.description: The logical structure of evolutionary theory, fitness, taxonomy, the notion of a living thing, reductionism, evolutionary explanations, teleology.

PHIL453.title: Philosophy of Psychology
PHIL453.description: Topics may include reasoning, the relationship between language and thought, concepts, moral cognition, and emotions.

PHIL454.title: Philosophy, History, and the Social Sciences
PHIL454.description: The nature of historical explanation, structural and functional explanation, the weighing of historical testimony, the concept of meaning, normative judgments and predictions in the social sciences.

PHIL455.title: Symbolic Logic
PHIL455.description: Introduction for graduates and advanced undergraduates.

PHIL456.title: Advanced Symbolic Logic
PHIL456.description: Presupposes propositional and quantificational logic as a basis of further deductive development with special attention to selected topics: alternative systems, modal and deontic logic, inductive logic, the grammar of formalized languages, paradoxes, and foundations of mathematics.

PHIL457.title: Set Theory and Logic
PHIL457.description: Natural and real numbers. Infinite cardinal and ordinal numbers. Alternative axiom systems and their consistency problems.

PHIL458.title: Formal Techniques in Philosophy
PHIL458.description: In a variety of subfields of philosophy, philosophers have found formal techniques to be useful tools for making progress on important philosophical questions. These subfields include, but are not limited to: metaphysics, epistemology, philosophy of language, philosophy of mind, ethics, and political philosophy. This course is a general introduction to some of the formal tools that have been most influential in these fields.

PHIL459.title: Philosophy of Mathematics
PHIL459.description: Philosophical problems concerning logic and the foundation of mathematics.

PHIL460.title: History of Moral Philosophy
PHIL460.description: Examination of classic texts of Plato, Aristotle, Aquinas, Hobbes, Butler, Hume, Kant, and Mill. Selections may vary from year to year.

PHIL462.title: Contemporary Moral Philosophy
PHIL462.description: Advanced discussion of moral issues such as fact and value, reason and morality, the nature of morality.

PHIL463.title: Contemporary Moral and Social Problems
PHIL463.description: Two courses in philosophy other than PHIL 155 strongly recommended. A detailed examination of one or more of the following contemporary issues: environmental ethics, animal rights, abortion, euthanasia, pornography, racism, sexism, public versus private morality.

PHIL464.title: Moral Responsibility
PHIL464.description: An intensive study of classic and recent work on the nature of moral responsibility and its relationship to blame (and praise).

PHIL465.title: Justice in Health Care
PHIL465.description: One course in philosophy strongly recommended. Medical students welcome. The course will focus on the question of how scarce health care resources ought to be distributed in order to meet the demands of justice.

PHIL468.title: Risk and Society
PHIL468.description: One additional course in philosophy strongly recommended. The course examines attitudes toward risk and how they affect our preferences for different public policies in the areas of environmental protection, technology regulation, and workplace and product safety.

PHIL470.title: Political Philosophy from Hobbes to Rousseau
PHIL470.description: Two courses in philosophy other than PHIL 155, including PHIL 170 or 370, strongly recommended. Explores the foundations of justice and authority in the idea of contract or covenant, the nature of law, rights, liberty, and democracy in the work of Hobbes, Locke, Hume, Rousseau.

PHIL471.title: Topics in 19th Century Philosophy
PHIL471.description: An examination of central issues in social and political philosophy as they figure in the work of 19th Century Philosophy.

PHIL473.title: American Political Philosophy
PHIL473.description: One course in philosophy other than PHIL 155 strongly recommended. The issue of unity and diversity in America is analyzed through the writings of Jefferson, the Federalists and Anti-Federalists, Calhoun, MacKinnon, DuBois, and Rawls.

PHIL474.title: Foundations of Modern Political Philosophy
PHIL474.description: This course traces the emergence and development of central themes of modern political philosophy from the 13th through the 17th century.

PHIL475.title: Philosophical Issues in Gender, Race, and Class
PHIL475.description: Examines in greater depth and complexity one or more of the issues addressed in PHIL 275, investigating issues of gender, race, and class within the dominant theories of philosophy.

PHIL476.title: Recent Developments in Political Philosophy
PHIL476.description: Two courses in philosophy other than PHIL 155, including PHIL 370, strongly recommended. Investigation of major contemporary contributors (Rawls, Nozick, Dworkin, Cohen, Waldron, Arrow) to philosophical debate concerning justice, equality, liberty, democracy, public reason, or rights versus community.

PHIL480.title: Philosophy of Law
PHIL480.description: An exploration of whether and under what conditions the state has the right to control crime by punishment of past crimes and preventive detention to prevent future crimes.

PHIL482.title: Philosophy and Literature
PHIL482.description: Philosophical readings of literary texts, including novels, plays, and poems.

PHIL485.title: Philosophy of Art
PHIL485.description: Competing theories of art and art criticism. The relationship between art and emotional expression, the formal character of art, and standards of taste.

PHIL491.title: Health Care, Science, and Philosophy
PHIL491.description: Interdisciplinary course to develop critical thinking capacities through philosophical study of the nature of scientific presuppositions and concepts, including events, causality, and determinism, with specific application to health care issues.

PHIL494.title: Existentialism and Phenomenology
PHIL494.description: A study of one or two major systematic works by Sartre, Heidegger, or Merleau-Ponty.

PHIL496.title: Advanced Directed Studies
PHIL496.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Advanced independent work in philosophy.

PHIL562.title: Ethics, Responsibility, and Justice
PHIL562.description: Ethics explores obligations to act in the interest of others as well as ourselves. Justice explores the ways people should organize and govern themselves. Course addresses such questions as, What principles govern our relationships with other people? What do we owe others and ourselves? How should we treat other people?

PHIL691H.title: Courses for Honors
PHIL691H.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. See the director of undergraduate studies of the department.

PHIL692H.title: Courses for Honors
PHIL692H.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. See the director of undergraduate studies of the department.

PHIL698.title: Philosophy, Politics, and Economics: Capstone Course
PHIL698.description: Permission of the department. This capstone course advances PHIL 384, focusing on such theoretical and philosophical issues as the analysis of rights or distributive justice and the institutional implications of moral forms.

PHIL740.title: Advanced Studies in Philosophy of Mind

PHIL745.title: Advanced Studies in Philosophy of Language

PHIL750.title: Advanced Studies in Philosophy of Science

PHIL755.title: Advanced Studies in Philosophy of Logic

PHIL780.title: Advanced Studies in Philosophy of Law

PHIL785.title: Advanced Studies in Philosophy, Politics, and Economics
PHIL785.description: This course provides Philosophy graduate students with the background to teach PPE courses. It covers core ideas in Economics and Political Science, Rationality, the Market, Inequality, Causal Inference, with the aim of analyzing social problems in PPE style.

PHIL840.title: Research Seminar in Philosophy of Mind

PHIL845.title: Research Seminar in Philosophy of Language

PHIL850.title: Research Seminar in Philosophy of Science

PHIL855.title: Research Seminar in Philosophy of Logic

PHIL880.title: Research Seminar in Philosophy of Law

PHYS50.title: First-Year Seminar: Time and the Medieval Cosmos
PHYS50.description: This course introduces first-year students to the basic motions of the solar system as viewed from the Earth along with the mechanical and mathematical models used to reproduce them, while exploring the history of medieval and early modern education, theology, and natural philosophy.

PHYS51.title: First-Year Seminar: The Interplay of Music and Physics
PHYS51.description: How sound is produced in instruments, and how those sounds are used in music making. Wave motion, resonance, sound perception, scales, harmony, and music theory. Collaborative laboratory exercises to investigate the acoustics of string, woodwind, and brass instruments as well as study of the physics of keyboard and percussion instruments. Students will make instruments from found objects and perform compositions on them, and can pursue their areas of special interest in a research paper.

PHYS53.title: First-Year Seminar: Handcrafting in the Nanoworld: Building Models and Manipulating Molecules
PHYS53.description: This seminar provides a general introduction to nanoscience and nanotechnology, focusing on recent advances in molecular electronics, nanomaterials, and biomedical research. Course activities include group model-building projects, presentations, and discussions of reading material.

PHYS54.title: First-Year Seminar: Physics of Movies
PHYS54.description: Students watch and analyze short movie clips that demonstrate interesting, unusual, or impossible physics. Group analysis emphasized.

PHYS55.title: First-Year Seminar: Introduction to Mechatronics
PHYS55.description: Introduction to important skills and knowledge required in the STEM fields of today and tomorrow, from academic, employment, and social perspectives. All students, regardless of their educational goals, will achieve critical introductory skills in numerical reasoning and analysis, engineering design and prototyping, computer programming and electronics, and will demonstrate proficiency and knowledge about topics that increasingly impact society, including Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, and Quantum Computing.

PHYS63.title: First-Year Seminar: Catastrophe and Chaos: Unpredictable Physics
PHYS63.description: Physics is often seen as the most precise and deterministic of sciences. Determinism can break down, however. This seminar explores the rich and diverse areas of modern physics in which "unpredictability" is the norm. Honors version available.

PHYS89.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics
PHYS89.description: Special Topics course. Content will vary each semester.

PHYS100.title: How Things Work
PHYS100.description: Demystifying the working of objects such as CD players, microwave ovens, lasers, computers, roller coasters, rockets, light bulbs, automobiles, clocks, copy machines, X-ray and CAT-scan machines, and nuclear reactors.

PHYS101.title: Basic Concepts of Physics
PHYS101.description: This is an introductory physics course for non-science majors. This course focuses on basic physics concepts and connections to everyday life. Course topics include Newtonian mechanics, fluids, heat, vibrations, electricity and magnetism, light and sound, quantum phenomenon, nuclear radiation, relativity, and cosmology. Connections to everyday life and society include energy conservation, global warming, nuclear energy, the origin of the universe, pseudoscience, and the search for extraterrestrial life.

PHYS108.title: Climate and Energy Transitions: Understanding the Forecasts
PHYS108.description: This course examines uncertainties in projecting future fossil fuel consumption and impact on global climate by quantifying how effectively alternative power-generation and energy-storage technologies can scale to meet needs in developing and developed nations, and by understanding past and present climates. Course previously offered as GEOL 108/MASC 108.

PHYS114.title: General Physics I: For Students of the Life Sciences
PHYS114.description: Basic principles of physics, including forces, energy, oscillations, sound, diffusion, and heat transfer, and applications to biological systems. Intended to meet the needs of, but not restricted to, students majoring in the life sciences. Students may not receive credit for PHYS 114 in addition to PHYS 104, 116, or 118.

PHYS115.title: General Physics II: For Students of the Life Sciences
PHYS115.description: Basic principles of physics, including fluids, electricity, magnetism, optics, quantum physics, and nuclear physics, and applications to biological systems. Intended to meet the needs of, but not restricted to, students majoring in the life sciences. Students may not receive credit for PHYS 115 in addition to PHYS 105, 117, or 119.

PHYS118.title: Introductory Calculus-based Mechanics and Relativity
PHYS118.description: Mechanics of particles and rigid bodies. Newton's laws; mechanical and potential energy; mechanical conservation laws; frame-dependence of physical laws; Einstein's Theory of Relativity. Students may not receive credit for PHYS 118 in addition to PHYS 104, 114, or 116. Honors version available.

PHYS119.title: Introductory Calculus-based Electromagnetism and Quanta
PHYS119.description: Unification of the laws of electricity and magnetism; electromagnetic waves; the particle-wave duality; fundamental principles and applications of quantum mechanics. Students may not receive credit for PHYS 119 in addition to PHYS 105, 115, or 117. Honors version available.

PHYS128.title: Modern Physics
