WGST576.description: Introduces students to the study of Native American women through the perspectives of anthropology, history, and autobiography.

WGST583.title: Gender and Imperialism
WGST583.description: Required preparation, one course in gender or non-Western societies. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the preparation. Focuses on feminist perspectives on imperialism, the effects of imperialism on colonized and European women, women's participation in anti-imperialist movements; and the legacies of imperialism for feminism today.

WGST620.title: Women in Hispanic Literature
WGST620.description: The image of woman in 16th- and 17th-century Hispanic literature. A study of texts by Spanish and Spanish American authors. Readings in Spanish or in English translation. Lectures in English.

WGST662.title: Gender Issues in Planning and Development
WGST662.description: Permission of the instructor required for undergraduates. Examination of the environmental and health risks, policy institutions, processes, instruments, policy analysis, and major elements of American environmental policy. Lectures and case studies.

WGST664.title: Body and Suffering in Christian Mysticism
WGST664.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Medieval Christians consistently focused on the suffering body as a means of reflecting on Christ's sacrifice. This course considers how medical theories of cognition, gender, and pain influenced the potential role of the body in medieval mystical experience.

WGST665.title: Queer Latina/o Literature, Performance, and Visual Art
WGST665.description: This course explores literature, performance art, film, and photography by Latinas and Latinos whose works may be described as "queer" and that question terms and norms of cultural dominance.

WGST666.title: Queer Latina/o Photography and Literature
WGST666.description: This course explores Latina/o literature about photography in relation to photography by "queer" Latina/o artists and, through this double focus, poses certain questions about identity, subjectivity, and culture.

WGST691H.title: Honors in Women's Studies
WGST691H.description: Senior standing and permission of the department. The first semester of the yearlong honors thesis in women's and gender studies. Completing WGST 691H fulfills the WGST 695 requirement for the major.

WGST692H.title: Honors in Women's Studies
WGST692H.description: Permission of department. Second semester of the yearlong honors thesis project.

WGST695.title: Senior Seminar: Principles of Feminist Inquiry
WGST695.description: Required preparation, at least one additional WGST course and senior standing or permission of the instructor. Required for majors; strongly recommended for minors. An advanced writing-intensive course drawing on a student's interests and background. Major research of specific topics utilizing feminist perspectives. Honors version available.

WGST715.title: Feminism and Society
WGST715.description: Selected topics in feminist analysis of social life, with materials drawn from a global range of societies.

WGST725.title: Selected Readings in the Comparative or Global History of Women and Gender
WGST725.description: Readings in the history of women and gender in a comparative, global, or transnational perspective.

WGST726.title: French Feminist Theory
WGST726.description: An introduction to feminist literary theory, focusing on feminist writings from France (in translation) and their sources in psychoanalysis and poststructuralism. Anglo-American counterparts and adaptations of the French theorists in the United States will also be treated.

WGST730.title: Feminist and Gender Theory for Historians
WGST730.description: Readings in contemporary feminist and gender theory, focused especially on theories that address the construction, writing, and general practice of history.

WGST735.title: Readings in the History of Sexuality and Gender
WGST735.description: Readings on the historical study of gender and sexuality and on definitions of femininity and masculinity in different historical contexts.

WGST753.title: Gender, Sickness, and Society
WGST753.description: This seminar deals in depth and cross-culturally with the nature of gender and the ways in which social comprehension of gender, gender status, and gender relationships impinge upon differential experience of health and sickness of men and women from a historical and contemporary perspective.

WGST755.title: Readings in Medieval and Early Modern Women's History
WGST755.description: A readings course on the history of women, gender, and sexuality in Medieval Europe.

WGST768.title: Feminist Political Theory
WGST768.description: A survey of feminist approaches to politics and political inquiry.

WGST770.title: Readings in Modern European Women's and Gender History
WGST770.description: A readings course in the history of women in Europe since 1500.

WGST776.title: Gender, Race, and Class Issues in Education
WGST776.description: Provides an understanding of (and remedies for) the racism, sexism, and class divisions that schools can perpetuate. Examines curriculum, counseling, and interaction in classrooms; structure and leadership; and fundamental assumptions.

WGST777.title: Gender, Policy, and Leadership in Education
WGST777.description: Covers feminist critiques of organizational and political power structures in readings and discussions leading to group and individual research projects.

WGST790.title: Graduate Seminar in Women's Studies
WGST790.description: Explores the complex interaction between women's studies, feminist studies and gender studies as these fields have evolved within and across academic disciplines, intersecting with issues of race, class, ethnicity, masculinity, sexuality, and with practices of queer theory and cultural studies.

WGST796.title: Graduate Independent Reading and Research
WGST796.description: Permission of the instructor. Intensive reading and research in a student's chosen area of interest under faculty supervision. Results in a written report.

WGST820.title: Critical Ethnic Studies (CES): New Perspectives
WGST820.description: This course is devised to provide graduate students interested in theoretical interdisciplinary work with a sense of prevailing questions and critiques important to CES. CES takes on the more difficult questions of intersectional work, as it thinks through sovereignty and emancipation, identity and ontology, place, space and temporality. Each iteration of the course works itself through new perspectives in the field, challenging students to create new methodologies for their own work.

WGST851.title: Sociology of Gender
WGST851.description: Reviews theory on variation in men's and women's gender roles, with emphasis on industrialized societies and women's roles.

WGST858.title: Seminar in Feminist Studies of Film and Television
WGST858.description: Graduate standing required. This graduate seminar explores theoretical and practical points of contact between feminism, film, and television using psychoanalysis, narrative analysis, ideological analysis, and cultural studies.

WGST865.title: Readings in United States Women's and Gender History
WGST865.description: A readings course on the history of women and gender in the United States.

WGST890.title: Topics in Women's Studies
WGST890.description: This course allows faculty in WMST to offer graduate-level courses on special topics pertinent to their current research.

WGST975.title: Seminar in Women's and Gender History
WGST975.description: Writing seminar for graduate students on all levels who work on the history of women and gender.
